title: Lancaster, Texas
text:
Lancaster ( ) is a <a href="city">city</a> in <a href="Dallas%20County%2C%20Texas">Dallas County, Texas</a>, United States. Its population was 41,275 according to the <a href="2010%20United%20States%20Census">2020 census</a>. Founded in 1852 as a frontier post, Lancaster is one of Dallas County's earliest settlements. Today, it is a suburban community located in the <a href="Dallas%E2%80%93Fort%20Worth%20metroplex">Dallas–Fort Worth metroplex</a>, about south of <a href="downtown%20Dallas">downtown Dallas</a>.
Lancaster is part of the <a href="Best%20Southwest">Best Southwest</a> area, which includes Lancaster, <a href="Cedar%20Hill%2C%20Texas">Cedar Hill</a>, <a href="DeSoto%2C%20Texas">DeSoto</a>, and <a href="Duncanville%2C%20Texas">Duncanville</a>.
History.
Early settlement.
In 1841, an act of the <a href="Republic%20of%20Texas">Republic of Texas</a> <a href="Congress%20of%20the%20Republic%20of%20Texas">Congress</a> authorized President <a href="Mirabeau%20Lamar">Mirabeau Lamar</a> to enter into a contract with William S. Peters and 19 associates to promote settlement in <a href="North%20Texas">North Texas</a>, and paid the company with free land in exchange for recruiting new settlers. Around 600 families settled in what became known as <a href="Peters%20Colony">Peters Colony</a> from 1841 through 1844. The Peters' group advertised heavily in <a href="Kentucky">Kentucky</a>, <a href="Illinois">Illinois</a>, <a href="Missouri">Missouri</a>, and <a href="Tennessee">Tennessee</a>, so many of the earliest settlers were from those states. The first group to settle in the Lancaster area was Roderick Rawlins and his family from <a href="Greene%20County%2C%20Illinois">Greene County, Illinois</a>. They left for Texas in September 1844. Rawlins and two of his sons-in-law came ahead to select the general area where they would settle. They chose an uninhabited area south of Dallas along the north bank of Ten Mile Creek as the site of their new settlement. In December 1844, the three men went back to <a href="Lamar%20County%2C%20Texas">Lamar County</a> near the <a href="Red%20River%20of%20the%20South">Red River</a> to bring the rest of their wagon train. All of the settlers had arrived by January 2, 1845, and they formed a community known as Hardscrabble. It consisted of two rows of log cabins with a street running north and south. In total, 30 men, women, and children lived in Hardscrabble.
Several miles north of Hardscrabble, a second community called Pleasant Run was established in 1846 by Polly Rawlins, one of Roderick's daughters, and her husband Madison Moultrie "M.M." Miller. Together, the Millers built a two-room structure, with one room used as a general store and the other for living. By 1848, the structure had grown to 15 rooms, a separate store, and a warehouse. A post office was established with biweekly mail delivery and Miller as postmaster. By 1850, he had laid out a town and sold lots, but never filed a plat of the community with Dallas County. At its peak, Pleasant Run boasted a stage stop, school, and steam-powered grist mill in addition to Miller's store. Accelerated by the death of M.M. Miller in 1860, Pleasant Run declined. Shortly after the Rawlins' settlers abandoned the Hardscrabble settlement, Lancaster became the dominant community in the area.
Founding of Lancaster.
The founder of Lancaster was "A" Bledsoe (Some sources list his name as Abram Bledsoe. or Albert A. Bledsoe). He was born in <a href="Lancaster%2C%20Kentucky">Lancaster, Kentucky</a>, in 1801. According to family lore, when his father Moses first looked at his newborn son, he is said to have remarked, "he looks like a Bledsoe." Thus his name, A Bledsoe, is unmarked by a period.
Bledsoe surveyed and staked off the original town of Lancaster in 1852. He purchased 430 acres of land from the widow of Roderick Rawlins, and modeled it after his Kentucky hometown. The layout featured a town square with streets entering from the center of each side rather than from the corners. Bledsoe began selling lots at a public auction in 1853, reportedly giving as many as two-thirds of them to settlers from the nearby Pleasant Run community. The official plat of the town of Lancaster was not filed with Dallas County until 1857. Bledsoe later served as Dallas County judge and <a href="Texas%20Comptroller%20of%20Public%20Accounts">state comptroller</a>. He died in 1882.
In 1860, a post office was established in Lancaster.
Progress and challenges.
During the <a href="American%20Civil%20War">American Civil War</a>, the Tucker, Sherrod &and Company contracted with the State of Texas to manufacture replicas of the .44 caliber <a href="Colt%20Dragoon">Colt Dragoon</a> from a factory on West Main Street in Lancaster. <a href="John%20M.%20Crockett">John M. Crockett</a>, former mayor of Dallas and lieutenant governor of Texas, served as superintendent of the arms factory. In the early years of <a href="Reconstruction%20Era">Reconstruction</a>, a drought crippled the economy to such an extent that few residents could afford more than the most basic of necessities. The economy did not fully recover until well into the 1870s, due in large part to the town's proximity to heavily trafficked cattle trails. The first public well was dug in the city's town square in 1876. Fires destroyed parts of the square in 1877, 1889, and again in 1918, each time being promptly rebuilt. Local telephone service came to Lancaster in 1881. Lancaster was incorporated on May 5, 1886. One year later, the "Lancaster Herald" newspaper began printing.
In December 1888, Lancaster's train depot opened as a stop on the <a href="Dallas%20and%20Waco%20Railway">Dallas and Waco Railway</a>. In 1891, it became part of the <a href="Missouri%E2%80%93Kansas%E2%80%93Texas%20Railroad">Missouri–Kansas–Texas Railroad</a> (MKT) line, running from Dallas to the <a href="Gulf%20Coast">Gulf Coast</a> of Texas. The <a href="Lancaster%20Tap%20Railroad">Lancaster Tap Railroad</a>, completed in 1890, connected the MKT line in Lancaster with the Dallas-<a href="Houston">Houston</a> line of the <a href="Houston%20and%20Texas%20Central%20Railway">Houston and Texas Central Railway</a> (H&TC) in <a href="Hutchins%2C%20Texas">Hutchins</a>, 4.5 miles away. It operated for 44 years. Rene Paul "R.P." Henry opened the first official bank in 1889. By 1897, the town had a public school, <a href="Masonic%20Temple">Masonic Temple</a>, a chapter of the <a href="International%20Order%20of%20Odd%20Fellows">International Order of Odd Fellows</a>, and a variety of Christian churches. From 1898 to 1901, <a href="Texas%20Christian%20University">Texas Christian University</a> founder <a href="Randolph%20Clark">Randolph Clark</a> established Randolph College in Lancaster. After its closure, the facilities were used continuously until they burned in a 1912 fire.
Early 20th century.
At the start of the 20th century, Lancaster had 1,045 residents and served hundreds more from the surrounding rural areas who worked, worshiped, attended school, and made their purchases in the town. The <a href="Texas%20Legislature">Texas Legislature</a> created the <a href="Lancaster%20Independent%20School%20District">Lancaster Independent School District</a> in March 1905, and voters approved several bond elections over the next decade that improved educational facilities. Electric lighting was introduced in 1911 via the Texas Power and Light Company, when the interurban <a href="Texas%20Electric%20Railway">Texas Electric Railway</a> (Dallas to <a href="Waco%2C%20Texas">Waco</a>) ran through town. Lancaster remained tied to its surrounding agricultural lands. Farmers produced a wide range of crops, including wheat, cotton, beans, peas, and sweet potatoes. Many agricultural-related businesses also thrived until the <a href="Dust%20Bowl">Dust Bowl</a> and <a href="Great%20Depression">Great Depression</a> caused the economy to contract. On February 27, 1934, Clyde Barrow of <a href="Bonnie%20%26amp%3B%20Clyde">Bonnie & Clyde</a> fame robbed the R.P. Henry and Sons Bank that was then located near the southeast corner of the town square. Bonnie Parker waited in the getaway car on Malloy Bridge Road while Clyde and Raymond Hamilton walked in, robbed the bank, and walked out with over $4,000. In June 1936, a storm toppled Lancaster's 50,000-gallon water tower, brought down utility poles, and damaged many homes. In the early 1940s, the economic climate began to show improvement.
Suburbanization.
Between 1900 and 1940, Lancaster's population grew slowly, ranging between 1,000 and 1,200 at each census. In 1950, the population had risen to just over 2,600. Soon after, the growth rate rapidly increased as Lancaster began to transform from a small town into a suburban <a href="Commuter%20town">bedroom community</a> of Dallas. By 1960, 7,501 residents were living in the city, a 185% increase over the 1950 figure. Highlights of the 1970s included a 1975 urban renewal project to improve the town square, which had suffered a loss of businesses to areas outside of downtown, and the opening of <a href="Cedar%20Valley%20College">Cedar Valley College</a> in 1977. Significant development continued into the 1980s. A hospital, two shopping centers, four schools, several apartment complexes, and a number of new residential subdivisions were built to accommodate the growing population.
Recent history.
On the night of <a href="April%201994%20tornado%20outbreak">April 25, 1994</a>, a violent F4 tornado ripped through Lancaster, killing three and injuring nearly 50 others. More than 250 homes and every building on the town square were heavily damaged or completely destroyed by the roughly half-mile-wide tornado. The White and Company Bank building, a local landmark since 1898, was severely damaged in the tornado, but was rebuilt, and in 1998, reopened as headquarters for the Lancaster Economic Development Corporation.
In 2005 and 2006, Lancaster was a finalist for the All-America City Award. In 2007 the <a href="National%20Arbor%20Day%20Foundation">National Arbor Day Foundation</a> designated Lancaster a <a href="Tree%20City%20USA">Tree City USA</a>.
Between 2000 and 2010, Lancaster's population increased by 40%, making it one of the fastest-growing cities in Dallas County during the decade.
On April 3, 2012, an EF-2 tornado struck the city as part of the <a href="Tornado%20outbreak%20of%20April%203%2C%202012">tornado outbreak</a>; 300 structures were reported damaged. A <a href="tornado%20emergency">tornado emergency</a> was not called for Lancaster, but a tornado emergency was called for the nearby cities of Dallas, <a href="Greenville%2C%20Texas">Greenville</a>, and <a href="Arlington%2C%20Texas">Arlington</a>. No deaths were reported from either the Lancaster tornado or any other tornado that day.
On June 23, 2019, Lancaster was one of 10 U.S. communities selected to receive the <a href="All-America%20City%20Award">All-America City Award</a> from the <a href="National%20Civic%20League">National Civic League</a>. The city was recognized for its civic engagement and robust communications to address community health concerns through: the development of new and improvement of existing parks; a community health challenge with runs, walks and health fairs; and a robust workplace wellness program.
Geography.
Lancaster is located in southern Dallas County and is part of the Dallas–Fort Worth metroplex, the largest metropolitan area in Texas. According to the <a href="United%20States%20Census%20Bureau">United States Census Bureau</a>, the city has a total area of , of which are land and is covered by water. On November 14, 2011, a tract of land covering within Lancaster's extraterritorial jurisdiction (ETJ) was annexed to the city.
Lancaster is situated within the <a href="Texas%20blackland%20prairies">Blackland Prairie</a> region of Texas, which is characterized by level to gently rolling topography. <a href="Ten%20Mile%20Creek%20%28Texas%29">Ten Mile Creek</a> and its tributaries are major drainage features in and around the city. Because the area was used for farming and other agricultural businesses, much of the natural vegetation has been cleared. Areas near creeks have retained some of their original tree cover, which includes pecan trees, cedar elms, and several species of oaks.
Climate.
Lancaster is located within the <a href="humid%20subtropical%20climate">humid subtropical climate</a> zone (<a href="K%C3%B6ppen%20climate%20classification">Köppen climate classification</a>: "Cfa"), which is characterized by hot, humid summers and mild to cool winters. Typically, July is the warmest month and January is the coolest month. The maximum average precipitation occurs in May.
Demographics.
2010 Census.
At the <a href="2010%20United%20States%20Census">2010 United States Census</a> 36,361 people, 12,520 households, and 9,252 families were residing in the city. The <a href="population%20density">population density</a> was 1,200.8/sq mi(463.6 km2). The 13,622 housing units averaged 449.9/sq mi (173.7 km2). The <a href="Race%20%28U.S.%20Census%29">racial makeup</a> of the city was 68.75% African American, 20.38% White (12.90% <a href="Non-Hispanic%20Whites">non-Hispanic White</a>), 0.35% Native American 0.29% Asian, 8.16 from other races, and 2.08% from two or more races. Hispanics or Latinos of any race were 16.95% of the population.
Of the 12,520 households, 39.1% had children under 18 living with them, 41.2% married couples living together, 27.1% had a female householder with no husband present, and 26.1% were not families. About 22.3% of all households were made up of individuals, and 4.7% had someone living alone who was 65 or older. The average household size was 2.88, and the average family size was 3.36.
The age distribution in the city was 31.2% under 18, 8.9% from 18 to 24, 29.4% from 25 to 44, 23.3% from 45 to 64, and 7.2% who were 65 or older. The median age was 32.3 years. For every 100 females, there were 84.6 males. For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 78.5 males.
2000 Census.
As of the <a href="census">census</a> of 2000, 25,894 people, 9,182 households, and 6,895 families ere residing in the city. As of the 2000 census, Lancaster is the largest African American-majority city in Texas.
Of the 9,182 households, 40.6% had children under 18 living with them, 49.4% were married couples living together, 20.8% had a female householder with no husband present, and 24.9% were not families. About 21.3% of all households were made up of individuals, and 6.3% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was 2.77, and the average family size was 3.22.
In the city, age distribution was 30.5% under 18, 8.6% from 18 to 24, 32.3% from 25 to 44, 19.6% from 45 to 64, and 9.0% who were 65 or older. The median age was 32 years. For every 100 females, there were 85.7 males. For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 80.9 males.
The median income for a household in the city was $43,773, and for a family was $48,498. Males had a median income of $33,406 versus $30,653 for females. The <a href="per%20capita%20income">per capita income</a> for the city was $18,731. About 6.1% of families and 8.1% of the population were below the <a href="poverty%20line">poverty line</a>, including 11.1% of those under age 18 and 8.7% of those age 65 or over.
Economy.
In its early years, Lancaster was an agrarian market center for the surrounding area. The arrival of railroads in the late 19th century transformed the community into a transportation hub. As the city has grown, the economic base has diversified. Today, light industrial manufacturing, distribution, health care, education, residential development, and retail services are all significant components of the local economy.
Lancaster has attracted the attention of logistics-related companies in recent years. The city's location in the fast-growing Dallas–Fort Worth metroplex region, land availability, easy access to three major interstate highways, Lancaster Regional Airport, and a planned 200-acre <a href="BNSF%20Railway">BNSF</a> intermodal freight facility round out the logistic options of road, rail, and air for the transport of goods. Park 20/35 at the northeast corner of Houston School Road and Cedardale Road is the largest logistics business park in Lancaster. It was developed in 2006 and now houses manufacturing and warehouse facilities for <a href="Quaker%20Oats%20Company">Quaker Oats/PepsiCo</a>, <a href="Mars%2C%20Incorporated%23Mars%20Petcare">Mars Petcare</a> and <a href="BMW">BMW</a> among others.

Government.
Local government.
The City of Lancaster is a home-rule city with a <a href="council%E2%80%93manager%20government">council–manager government</a>. Under this type of local government, the day-to-day management of the city is directed by a <a href="city%20manager">city manager</a>, who is appointed by the city council and serves as chief administrative officer for the city. Opal Mauldin Robertson is the current city manager of Lancaster.
The seven-member city council consists of the mayor, who represents the city as a whole and is elected at-large, and six members elected in single-member districts. The current electoral system was implemented in 1994. The mayor and city council members serve staggered three-year terms. Clyde C. Hairston is the current mayor of Lancaster.
Lancaster is a voluntary member of the <a href="North%20Central%20Texas%20Council%20of%20Governments">North Central Texas Council of Governments</a>, the purpose of which is to co-ordinate individual and collective local governments and facilitate regional solutions, eliminate unnecessary duplication, and enable joint decisions.
State and national representation.
Lancaster is located in <a href="Texas%27s%2030th%20congressional%20district">Texas' 30th congressional district</a> of the <a href="United%20States%20House%20of%20Representatives">U.S. House of Representatives</a> and is represented by <a href="Democratic%20Party%20%28United%20States%29">Democrat</a> <a href="Eddie%20Bernice%20Johnson">Eddie Bernice Johnson</a>. In the <a href="Texas%20Legislature">Texas Legislature</a>, Lancaster is in <a href="Texas%20Senate%2C%20District%2023">District 23</a> of the <a href="Texas%20Senate">Texas Senate</a>, represented by Democrat <a href="Royce%20West">Royce West</a>. In the <a href="Texas%20House%20of%20Representatives">Texas House of Representatives</a>, the city is part of <a href="Texas%20House%20of%20Representatives%2C%20District%20109">District 109</a>, which is represented by Democrat <a href="Carl%20Sherman%20%28Texas%20politician%29">Carl Sherman, Sr</a>.
Education.
Primary and secondary schools.
Lancaster is served mainly by the <a href="Lancaster%20Independent%20School%20District">Lancaster Independent School District</a> (LISD). The school district consists of 11 campuses: seven elementary schools, one sixth grade center, one middle school, one <a href="Lancaster%20High%20School%20%28Lancaster%2C%20Texas%29">high school</a>, and an alternative school. Approximately 6,800 students were enrolled in LISD as of Fall 2013.
The <a href="Dallas%20Independent%20School%20District">Dallas Independent School District</a> (DISD) serves a small portion of the city that includes the subdivisions of Cedardale Highlands, Taylor Brothers, and Lancaster Gardens. Students living in this area are zoned to Wilmer-Hutchins Elementary School, Kennedy-Curry Middle School, and <a href="Wilmer-Hutchins%20High%20School">Wilmer-Hutchins High School</a>. The area had been part of the <a href="Wilmer-Hutchins%20Independent%20School%20District">Wilmer-Hutchins Independent School District</a> (WHISD) until the district was ordered closed prior to the start of the 2005–2006 school year. Dallas ISD agreed to absorb WHISD after Lancaster, which was given the first option to take over the district, declined.
Two public charter schools are in the city. <a href="Life%20School">Life School Lancaster</a> opened in 2007 and serves students from kindergarten through sixth grade. In January 2012, the <a href="http%3A//www.aiacharterschools.org/index.cfm%3FpID%3D5656">Accelerated Intermediate Academy</a> (AIA) opened an elementary campus in Lancaster on East Belt Line Road.
<a href="http%3A//www.southwestacademies.com/private-schooling-services">Berne Academy</a> is the sole private school in Lancaster.
Colleges and universities.
<a href="Cedar%20Valley%20College">Cedar Valley College</a>, a two-year accredited institution affiliated with the <a href="Dallas%20County%20Community%20College%20District">Dallas County Community College District</a> (DCCCD) is located on the border of Lancaster and Dallas. The college offers workforce training, continuing 
education, and college preparatory programs. As of spring 2013, 6,375 students were enrolled at the campus.
The <a href="University%20of%20North%20Texas%20at%20Dallas">University of North Texas at Dallas</a> campus is located just north of the Lancaster city limits in far southern Dallas.
Public library.
<a href="http%3A//lancaster-tx.com/index.aspx%3FNID%3D149">Lancaster Veterans Memorial Library</a> is located in Lancaster Community Park. The library relocated from a building on West Main Street in downtown to its present location in May 2001. The 23,000 square foot facility includes a public meeting room, reading lounge, and genealogical center. Lancaster residents can obtain a library card free of charge, which entitles the bearer to borrow materials and use the public-access internet computers. Nonresidents may purchase a library card for a nominal, annual fee.
Just north of the library is a paved contemplative garden funded by the nonprofit Friends of the Lancaster Veterans Memorial Library organization.
Media.
Lancaster's <a href="newspaper%20of%20record">newspaper of record</a> is the "<a href="Focus%20Daily%20News">Focus Daily News</a>". The DeSoto-based daily newspaper serves the southern suburbs of Dallas and is currently the largest circulation suburban daily newspaper in Texas.
Parks and recreation.
The responsibilities of Lancaster's Parks and Recreation Department include park maintenance, recreation programs, and management of recreational facilities.
Parks.
The system of public parks in Lancaster covers more than 600 acres. The 170-acre Lancaster Community Park is the most-used park in the city. It features a 6-acre pond known as Contemplation Lake with a fishing pier, lighted football and soccer fields, hiking/biking trails, playground, amphitheater, and the Royce Clayton Baseball Field, which has a covered grandstand that can seat 500 spectators. The Recreation Center, Senior Life Center, Library, and Public Safety Building are located in the park.
Lancaster City Park is another highly used park in the city with four baseball/softball fields, two playgrounds, two tennis courts, a basketball court, walking trail, and an off-leash area for dogs. The park also has two concession stands and two large pavilions, each with 15 tables. The Cedardale Park and Complex in northern Lancaster contains baseball/softball fields, a basketball court, playground, and concession stand. There are smaller neighborhood parks located throughout the city with playgrounds and other amenities. They are J.A. Dewberry Park, Jaycee Park, Kids Square Park, Meadowcreek Park, Rocky Crest Park, Stanford Park, and Verona Park. Heritage Park, which contains an iconic gazebo, is located north of the historic town square in downtown Lancaster. The newest addition to the park system is the 2.4 mile Pleasant Run Hike and Bike Trail, which opened in the spring of 2010 and is routed through neighborhoods in central Lancaster.
Two <a href="Nature%20reserve">nature preserves</a> have been established in Lancaster, Bear Creek Nature Park and the Ten Mile Creek Preserve. The 189-acre Bear Creek Nature Park was created on land purchased with a $500,000 matching grant from the <a href="Texas%20Parks%20and%20Wildlife%20Department">Texas Parks and Wildlife Department</a>. Features of the park site include equestrian and walking trails with interpretive signage, a fishing pond, climbing rock, <a href="Butterfly%20gardening">butterfly garden</a>, and a large pavilion for picnics. Additionally, there is an outdoor classroom and educational programs available for children. The Ten Mile Creek Preserve sits on land donated to the city by Dallas County. It remains largely undeveloped to protect the natural meadows and wooded areas. A two-mile unpaved trail runs through the preserve.
Facilities.
The 64,000-sq-ft Lancaster Recreation Center features an indoor water park, gymnasium, elevated jogging track, and fitness atrium with an aerobics/dance room. The building also includes a banquet room and catering kitchen that can be used for meetings and other social events. The banquet room has a covered outdoor terrace and courtyard that overlooks Contemplation Lake.
The Senior Life Center is a full-service activity center serving adults aged 50 years and older. The 11,500-sq-ft building opened in December 2008. The facility includes a dining hall, commercial kitchen, classrooms, computer lab, and reading lounge. Transportation to and from the center is available for Lancaster residents in need.
Country View Golf Course is an 18-hole, par-70 public golf course located on West Belt Line Road. It was designed by Florida architect Ron Garl, and opened for play in 1989. The course spans 6,461 yards from the back tee with Bermuda grass fairways. It has a chipping area, putting green, and driving range, as well as on-site golf pro shop and sports bar.
Culture.
Museums.
The 45,000-sq-ft <a href="http%3A//www.cwam.org/">Cold War Air Museum</a> is located on the grounds of Lancaster Regional Airport. Flying aircraft from the <a href="Cold%20War">Cold War</a> era are exhibited, with related artifacts, artwork, and library resources from that period. A portion of the museum is a working restoration facility, which actively returns Cold War-era aircraft to flying status.
Also located at Lancaster Regional Airport, the <a href="http%3A//www.contrails.us/caf_dfw_wing/index.htm">Commemorative Air Force Museum–Dallas/Fort Worth Wing</a> is dedicated to the preservation of combat aircraft of <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>.
The <a href="http%3A//www.lancaster-tx.com/index.aspx%3FNID%3D422">Lancaster Visitors Center ad State Auxiliary Museum</a> is located in the renovated Interurban Building at the corner of Dallas Avenue and Main Street; the museum contains exhibits and historical artifacts showcasing the history of Lancaster and the state. The building also houses the <a href="http%3A//www.lancastertexas.org/">Lancaster Chamber of Commerce</a> and visitors center.
The <a href="http%3A//www.lancasterisd.org/">Rocky Crest Museum</a> highlights a collection of historical items connected to Rocky Crest School - Lancaster's first school for African Americans, its former students, and the surrounding community. The museum is located at the J.D. Hall Learning Center on Second Street, site of the former Rocky Crest School.
Landmarks.
Lancaster has three properties listed on the <a href="National%20Register%20of%20Historic%20Places">National Register of Historic Places</a>: the <a href="Randlett%20House">Randlett House</a>, the <a href="Captain%20R.%20A.%20Rawlins%20House">Captain R. A. Rawlins House</a>, and the <a href="W.%20A.%20Strain%20Farm-Strain%20House">W. A. Strain Farm-Strain House</a>.
The <a href="Texas%20Historical%20Commission">Texas Historical Commission</a> has designated 14 sites in the Lancaster area with historical markers. Listed below are the sites in Lancaster with state historical markers and the year they received the designation:

Community events.
Several community events are held in Lancaster throughout the year. In January, the <a href="http%3A//www.lancastermlk.org/">Lancaster Martin Luther King, Jr. Foundation</a> hosts the annual MLK parade and gala.
The Lancaster Country Ride, sponsored by <a href="http%3A//www.greaterdallasbicyclists.com/">Greater Dallas Bicyclists (GDB)</a>, takes place each April. The route begins at the town square and traverses the back roads of Lancaster.
The annual <a href="Independence%20Day%20%28United%20States%29">July Fourth</a> celebration is held at Lancaster Community Park and features family activities, food, and a fireworks show. It is a joint collaboration between the cities of Lancaster and DeSoto.
The Dallas/Fort Worth Wing of the <a href="Commemorative%20Air%20Force">Commemorative Air Force</a> hosts <a href="http%3A//www.warbirdsonparade.com/">Warbirds on Parade</a> in the late summer (August/September). The event at Lancaster Regional Airport features restored World War II aircraft, military vehicles, memorabilia, and classic cars.
In October, an" <a href="Oktoberfest">Oktoberfest</a>" celebration is held by the <a href="http%3A//www.lhsweb.org/">Lancaster Historic Society</a>. Lancaster High School's <a href="homecoming">homecoming</a> parade is also held during the month.
A Christmas parade and festival is held in December. The festival includes a tree lighting, live entertainment, and carnival games.
The city sponsors four "Trash Off" events during the year. Residents participate by bringing bulk trash, recyclables, tires, scrap metal, brush, and electronic waste for disposal. Local organizations and volunteers also participate in clean-up campaigns across the city.
<a href="http%3A//lancastertexas.org/2nd-saturday-on-the-square/about-2nd-saturday-on-the-square">2nd Saturday on the Square</a> is a long-standing tradition in Lancaster. Held at the historic town square on the second Saturday of each month, the event features food, music, entertainment, and a variety of commercial vendors.
Infrastructure.
Transportation.
Lancaster is served by two <a href="Interstate%20Highway">interstate highways</a>. <a href="Interstate%2035E%20%28Texas%29">Interstate 35E</a> forms the western boundary of the city and east–west access is provided by <a href="Interstate%2020%20in%20Texas">Interstate 20</a>, located on the far-north side of Lancaster. <a href="Interstate%2045">Interstate 45</a> is situated approximately five miles to the east.
<a href="Arterial%20road">Principal thoroughfares</a> within the city include <a href="Texas%20State%20Highway%20342">State Highway 342</a> (running north–south, also known as Dallas Avenue), Houston School Road (north-south), Pleasant Run Road (east-west), and <a href="Belt%20Line%20Road%20%28Texas%29">Belt Line Road</a> (east-west).
<a href="Lancaster%20Regional%20Airport">Lancaster Regional Airport</a> is a public-use <a href="airport">airport</a> located two miles southeast of the central business district of Lancaster. Currently used for <a href="general%20aviation">general aviation</a> purposes, the airport is publicly owned by City of Lancaster and serves as a <a href="reliever%20airport">reliever airport</a> for <a href="Dallas%E2%80%93Fort%20Worth%20International%20Airport">Dallas–Fort Worth International Airport</a> and <a href="Dallas%20Love%20Field">Dallas Love Field</a>. It has one <a href="runway">runway</a> designated 13/31 with an <a href="asphalt">asphalt</a> surface measuring 6,502 by 100 feet (1,982 x 30 m).
The city has public transportation, and is not a member of <a href="Dallas%20Area%20Rapid%20Transit">Dallas Area Rapid Transit</a> (DART). The Cedar Valley College campus is served by Bus Route 553, which is currently the southernmost stop on DART.
Health care.
Crescent Medical Center Lancaster is an 84-bed acute-care general hospital located at 2600 West Pleasant Run Road. The hospital was formerly known as the Medical Center at Lancaster, which closed in 2008. After being purchased by new owners and undergoing major renovations, Crescent Medical Center opened on June 17, 2013.
